dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A rising tide lifts all boats, and right now, Jeff Bezos is calling for a celebration of that very tide—unrestrained capitalism.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And he's really pushing this idea that companies should be measured by quarterly profits and shareholder returns, not so much their external impact.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And he's really pushing this idea that companies should be measured by quarterly profits and shareholder returns, not so much their external impact.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In short, Nadella said, companies like Microsoft should be measured by the number of jobs and revenue created outside of the company and the economic impact they have on the markets where they operate, as opposed to surpluses generated within a company.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is interestingly inspired by a book from Jamie Dimon, I think? The management studies professor?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is interestingly inspired by a book from Jamie Dimon, I think? The management studies professor?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nadellas comments, which he says were inspired by a book published last year by Oxford management studies professor Colin Mayer, follow ongoing calls for business leaders to commit to steering their corporations toward so-called stakeholder capitalism.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, actually Jamie Dimon is the CEO of JPMorgan Chase—he was one of the nearly 300 CEOs who signed those new guidelines emphasizing shareholder returns earlier this year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, actually Jamie Dimon is the C E O of JPMorgan Chase-he was one of the nearly three hundred CEOs who signed those new guidelines emphasizing shareholder returns earlier this year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though a recent report cast doubt on just how committed these companies are to stakeholder capitalism, Nadella pointed to Microsofts pledge to become carbon neutral by 2030, and highlighted a push by LinkedIn to address racial inequality as initiatives supported by shareholders.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh right, right. But then Bezos also pointed to Amazon's own pledge to go carbon neutral by 2035 as something shareholders support.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh right, right. But then Bezos also pointed to Amazon's own pledge to go carbon neutral by twenty thirty five as something shareholders support.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though a recent report cast doubt on just how committed these companies are to stakeholder capitalism, Nadella pointed to Microsofts pledge to become carbon neutral by 2030, and highlighted a push by LinkedIn to address racial inequality as initiatives supported by shareholders.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm, which kind of complicates the message a bit, doesn't it? Like, he's advocating for shareholder focus but also highlighting these broader initiatives.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm, which kind of complicates the message a bit, doesn't it? Like, he's advocating for shareholder focus but also highlighting these broader initiatives.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And he mentioned Microsoft's efforts on racial inequality too—so it's not just about pure profit, but shareholders backing these bigger goals.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And he mentioned Microsoft's efforts on racial inequality too-so it's not just about pure profit, but shareholders backing these bigger goals.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though a recent report cast doubt on just how committed these companies are to stakeholder capitalism, Nadella pointed to Microsofts pledge to become carbon neutral by 2030, and highlighted a push by LinkedIn to address racial inequality as initiatives supported by shareholders.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then there's the context—Amazon's growth has actually slowed since 2010, partly because of lagging cloud services demand.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then there's the context-Amazon's growth has actually slowed since twenty ten, partly because of lagging cloud services demand.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since Nadella took over as Microsoft CEO in 2013, the company has experienced explosive growth, in large part thanks to a booming cloud services business a sector that has only recorded surging demand during the pandemic as the global workforce was forced to work from home.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, which makes his emphasis on a robust financial system even more pointed. He talked about Amazon's standing relying on the vibrancy of the economy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, which makes his emphasis on a robust financial system even more pointed. He talked about Amazon's standing relying on the vibrancy of the economy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As an American company and tech company our standing in the world, and in the United States, comes because of the vibrancy of the American democracy, Nadella told Andrea Jung, the CEO of Grameen America, who hosted the talk.

dialogue_turns.tts_text: He did say that to Andrea Jung from Grameen China, right? That any business's standing depends on building on strong economic influence.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As an American company and tech company our standing in the world, and in the United States, comes because of the vibrancy of the American democracy, Nadella told Andrea Jung, the CEO of Grameen America, who hosted the talk. So therefore any standing of any business, including ours, depends on us building on that strong institution of democracy here and everywhere else.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's a pretty firm stance, especially with the state election coming up and all the talk around Governor Newsom accepting outcomes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a pretty firm stance, especially with the state election coming up and all the talk around Governor Newsom accepting outcomes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Beyond the pandemic and racial justice issues, Nadella also discussed the upcoming federal election, which has been overshadowed by President Donald Trumps assertions he may not accept its outcome.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely feels like he's tying corporate success tightly to political and economic stability.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely feels like he's tying corporate success tightly to political and economic stability.

dialogue_turns.tts_text: So in a way, he's arguing that shareholder capitalism and these bigger societal goals aren't mutually exclusive?

artist_script:
HostA: A rising tide lifts all boats, and right now, Jeff Bezos is calling for a celebration of that very tide—unrestrained capitalism.
HostB: Yeah, he made those comments at the Fortune 500 virtual summit, didn’t he? Saying it’s fair to have a party for capitalism in 2023, given the economic surge.
HostA: Exactly. And he’s really pushing this idea that companies should be measured by quarterly profits and shareholder returns, not so much their external impact.
HostB: Which is interestingly inspired by a book from Jamie Dimon, I think? The management studies professor?
HostA: Uh, actually Jamie Dimon is the CEO of JPMorgan Chase—he was one of the nearly 300 CEOs who signed those new guidelines emphasizing shareholder returns earlier this year.
HostB: Oh right, right. But then Bezos also pointed to Amazon’s own pledge to go carbon neutral by 2035 as something shareholders support.
HostA: Mhm, which kind of complicates the message a bit, doesn’t it? Like, he’s advocating for shareholder focus but also highlighting these broader initiatives.
HostB: For sure. And he mentioned Microsoft’s efforts on racial inequality too—so it’s not just about pure profit, but shareholders backing these bigger goals.
HostA: But then there’s the context—Amazon’s growth has actually slowed since 2010, partly because of lagging cloud services demand.
HostB: Yeah, which makes his emphasis on a robust financial system even more pointed. He talked about Amazon’s standing relying on the vibrancy of the economy.
HostA: He did say that to Andrea Jung from Grameen China, right? That any business’s standing depends on building on strong economic influence.
HostB: It’s a pretty firm stance, especially with the state election coming up and all the talk around Governor Newsom accepting outcomes.
HostA: Definitely feels like he’s tying corporate success tightly to political and economic stability.
HostB: So in a way, he’s arguing that shareholder capitalism and these bigger societal goals aren’t mutually exclusive?
HostA: Seems like it—or at least that’s interests can align if framed the right way.
